content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.

Here is a way to solve this problem in Julia. We can use the DataFrames package which provides data structures and functionalities for manipulating tabular data.

```julia
using DataFrames

# Create dummy dataframe (replace with actual DataFrame)
df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "toyota", "ford", "bmw", "audi"], model=["a4", "corolla", "focus", "x3", "a4 quattro"])

# Define function
function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    # Filter the dataframe to only include rows with manufacturer as "audi" and model as "a4" or "a4 quattro"
    df = filter(row -> row.manufacturer == "audi", df)
    filter!(row -> (row.model == "a4" || row.model == "a4 quattro"), df)
    
    # Add a new column to indicate whether it's an Audi A4
    push!(df, :audi_a4_type => trues(size(df)[1])) 

    return df
end

# Call function and print resultant dataframe
result = audi_filter(df_cars)
print(result)
```

This script first creates a dummy DataFrame for demonstration purposes. Then it calls the `audi_filter` function on this DataFrame, filtering out rows that don't have "audi" as the manufacturer and model not being either "a4" or "a4 quattro". Finally, it adds a new column to indicate whether each row is an Audi A4, setting all values in this new column to `true`. The resulting DataFrame is then printed.
